support_summary: The transcription factor NRF2 (NFE2L2), a master regulator of the antioxidant response, indirectly activates TFEB. NRF2 activation, often through the loss of its inhibitor KEAP1, promotes TFEB/TFE3-dependent lysosomal biogenesis.

functions.cellular_process: Activation of the NRF2 antioxidant response pathway (e.g., via loss of its repressor KEAP1) leads to the aberrant activation of TFEB and TFE3, resulting in increased nuclear localization of TFEB/TFE3.
functions.effect_description: NRF2 indirectly drives a TFEB/TFE3-dependent transcriptional program for lysosomal biogenesis, linking the cellular antioxidant response to the regulation of lysosomal homeostasis.
biological_consequence: Loss of KEAP1 or oxidative stress → NRF2 (NFE2L2) stabilization and nuclear accumulation → NRF2 signaling promotes aberrant activation of TFEB/TFE3 → TFEB/TFE3 dephosphorylation and nuclear translocation is increased → Upregulation of the TFEB/TFE3-dependent lysosomal program → Enhanced lysosomal biogenesis.

evidence.paper_title: The KEAP1-NRF2 pathway regulates TFEB/TFE3-dependent lysosomal biogenesis
evidence.authors: Ong AJS, Bladen CE, Tigani TA, Karamalakis AP, Cipponi A, Rezcallah A, Rasko JEJ, Brown K, Cox AG
evidence.journal: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America
evidence.relevant_quote: loss of Keap1 promotes aberrant activation of transcription factor EB (TFEB)/transcription factor binding to IGHM Enhancer 3 (TFE3)-dependent lysosomal biogenesis.

mechanism: Activation of the NRF2 antioxidant response pathway (e.g., via loss of its repressor KEAP1) leads to the aberrant activation of TFEB and TFE3, resulting in increased nuclear localization of TFEB/TFE3.
effect: NRF2 indirectly drives a TFEB/TFE3-dependent transcriptional program for lysosomal biogenesis, linking the cellular antioxidant response to the regulation of lysosomal homeostasis.
summary: TFEB activates NFE2L2 to modulate tfeb/tfe3 activation & lysosomal biogenesis, ultimately affecting enhanced lysosomal biogenesis.

evidence.paper_title: The KEAP1-NRF2 pathway regulates TFEB/TFE3-dependent lysosomal biogenesis
evidence.authors: Ong AJS, Bladen CE, Tigani TA, Karamalakis AP, Cipponi A, Rezcallah A, Rasko JEJ, Brown K, Cox AG
evidence.journal: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America
evidence.relevant_quote: loss of Keap1 promotes aberrant activation of transcription factor EB (TFEB)/transcription factor binding to IGHM Enhancer 3 (TFE3)-dependent lysosomal biogenesis.
